Award.AwardTitle: EARS: Collaborative Research: Intelligence Measure of Cognitive Radio Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research on spectrum sharing has generated a large amount of spectrum measurement data and many spectrum sharing techniques. Most of the techniques are based on cognitive radio networks (CRNs) because the cognition capability is necessary for optimizing spectrum efficiency and guaranteeing safe coexistence in the presence of the spectrum uncertainty. Such cognitive capabilities collectively defines the intelligence of CRNs. Although cognition and intelligence are vital for CRNs, their quantitative specification is largely open.

This project addresses this open question by developing a framework for investigating quantitatively the cognitive capabilities and the intelligence of CRNs. This project develops both a theoretical approach and an empirical approach to construct a CRN intelligence model. This model is inspired from the Cattell-Horn-Carroll human intelligence model. On the other hand, the pioneering theoretical approach is in sharp contrast to conventional human intelligence research that is mainly empirical. In addition, this project develops a CRN testing battery to measure the intelligence as CRN IQ (intelligence quotient) following psychometric practices. Finally, this project initiates innovative research in IQ-based multi-hop routing and IQ-based immunity to Denial-of-Service attacks, where innovative CRN techniques are developed with the aim of enhancing important cognitive capabilities. This project adopts a big data approach to exploit the vast amount of existing spectrum measurement data and CRN research results. Psychometric techniques are exploited to resolve challenges involved in this big data application.

This project impacts society by expediting the commercial success of spectrum sharing technology. It integrates three traditionally disparate areas: wireless communications, psychology, and big data. The framework for constructing intelligence measure is useful to many other systems such as cognitive computing, cognitive control and cognitive radar. This project enhances the value of the spectrum measurement data and leads to a new direction for big data utilization. This project impacts education in many aspects, such as stimulating student research via the human intelligence analogy, supporting hands-on curriculum with the CRN testing battery, setting up CRN IQ competition projects, and outreaching to under-represented students and high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to resolve the impending spectrum shortage problem, sharing spectrum with legacy systems has attracted intensive research during the past decade. Cognitive radio networks (CRNs), which use cognitive capabilities to sense and adapt to the spectrum environment, can potentially achieve extremely high spectrum efficiency and guarantee the peaceful coexistence with legacy systems.  Nevertheless, the complex and uncertain spectrum environment makes spectrum sharing extremely challenging. The uncertainty may come from the radio propagation environment, the legacy system activity, or the complex behavior of the CRN itself.

Although the CRN was born with the idea of realizing “cognition”, the research on CRN cognition and intelligence was scarce. Considering the vital role of cognition and intelligence to the CRN, many important issues need to be addressed, such as how to quantify CRN intelligence, and how to enhance CRN performance from the intelligence perspective.

To fill this gap, for the first time, this project developed an intelligence measure to evaluate quantitatively the cognitive capability of the CRN, which can be further used to enhance the coexistence and spectrum efficiency of the CRN in an uncertain environment. Following human intelligence theory, specifically the widely accepted Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) intelligence model, we constructed a CRN intelligence model. Based on this model, we developed psychometric techniques to measure the CRN intelligence as CRN IQ (intelligence quotient). The intelligence model and the CRN IQ are then used to guide the development of new CRN techniques.

The PIs proposed a data-driven methodology to quantitatively measure the intelligence factors of the CR with learning capabilities. The basic idea of our methodology is to run various tests on the CR in different spectrum environments under different settings and obtain various performance data on different metrics. Then we applied factor analysis on the performance data to identify and quantize the intelligence factors and cognitive capabilities of the CR. More specifically, we presented a case study consisting of 144 different types of CRs. The CRs are different in terms of learning-based dynamic spectrum access strategies, number of sensors, sensing accuracy, processing speed, and algorithmic complexity. Five intelligence factors are identified for the CRs through our data analysis. We showed that these factors comply well with the nature of the tested CRs, which validates the proposed intelligence measure methodology.

To further enhance the CR intelligence testing efficiency, the PIs proposed a CR cognition evaluation methodology that include the following steps: 1) Construct standard test batteries that allow test-based evaluation on CRs, with weights coefficient of cognitive capabilities; 2) Optimize performance metrics in each standard test battery that embraces evaluation on every broad cognitive capabilities with minimal evaluation redundancy; 3) Construct standard reassemble-enabled CR models that allows flexible evaluation on CR techniques; 4) Exterminate standard test batteries to construct either application-oriented or general-purposed questionnaire that can measure the overall cognition. Furthermore, machine learning and human learning were applied jointly to optimize the training of linear regression. Human learning was exploited to label extra training data so as to resolve problems such as insufficient training and over-fitting. By exploiting the IRT (item response theory) to model the distribution of human errors, it reconstructs the training data set so that the human labeling errors become sparse. Simulations were conducted to show that the two algorithms are effective in resolving the insufficient training and human labeling error problems.

By utilizing the radio intelligence, the PIs proposed and evaluated several methods to detect malicious attacks in cognitive radio networks. The PIs proposed an adaptive and realistic primary user emulation (PUE) attack detection technique. The PIs also explored recurrent neural network for PUE attack detection in practical CRN models. The PIs proposed a recurrent neural network (RNN) based PUE attack detection method leveraging the energy-and-computation-efficient intermittent spectrum sensing technology. Further, a more advanced RNN technique, called long short-term memory (LSTM), was studied for the detection. Simulation results showed that the three-layer LSTM based PUE attack detector achieved the best detection performance.

Regarding broader impact, with the support of this project, five graduate students (including one female student) were trained on scientific survey, software defined radio (i.e., USRP) testbed building, experiment running, data analysis, MATLAB simulation, and scientific writing. Four undergraduate students (including one female student) were involved in the CRN research through the REU supplement grant. They were also trained on literature survey, testbed development, programming, experiment, and technical report writing. More than 15 peer-reviewed papers were published in reputable journals and conferences, including IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking, IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications, IEEE ICASSP, IEEE Globecom, etc. Three courses on networking and wireless security are enhanced through the integration of the research results into the course materials. This project built a small-scale cognitive radio testbed using USRP devices. This testbed will be used for senior design projects and open for researchers outside of the PI’s group.
